moves.2. Bc4 Nf6 3. d3 Nc6 4. Nf3 Bc5 5. Nc3 N: Breaks the rule of moving same piece more than once in the opening...but there's a clear and present danger on f2 now. So...
moves.6. d4: Removes the threat on f2 and attacks black's DSB
moves.6... exd4: Everyone loves the center pawn exchange more than the US stock exchange i bet
moves.7... Bxd4: I believe it may have been better for black if he focused on developing the LSB which is locked at this point
moves.8. Qxg4: Getting material back and attacking g7.
moves.9. Qg3: Protecting f2, and threatening c7 (if needed i suppose)
moves.9... Nb4: Threatening a fork from c2. I still think black should focus more on developing this early in the game.
moves.10... h5: Not sure...perhaps to threatening white's kingside?
moves.11. Be3: I don't like that d4 bishop so trying to move it away. if he exchanges bishop i'll have an open f-file for my rook
moves.11... Bxc3+: Threatening fork by Queen on c3 after 11...bxc3 12. Qxc3
moves.12. bxc3: Which I didn't see at that time
moves.12... d6: And apparently black didn't see the fork at c3 either. Bringing black's LSB into play
moves.13. O-O: Long live the king! Rooks are connected
moves.13... Nc6: Only move besides a6 (which would be a worse choice for a knight i think)
moves.14... Bg4: Black clearly doesn't like a rook on the open file. Developing bishop while attacking the rook...
moves.16. Qxg4 g5: Not sure why? maybe as a backup to the h pawn which didn't need it at this time. If I was black I would try to get white to capture the h4 pawn then double the rooks on the h file (I know it's a long shot but worth a try perhaps?)
moves.18. Qf5: Attacking f7, which is already being attacked by the LSB
moves.18... Nd4: Blunder!!! Black didn't see the impending doom...
moves.19. Qxf7#: Was a great game! I'd like to thank devdor for this game. I'm sure I made many blunders, but in the end it worked out.
